caption:
This is how I’m seeing a few people double their pay in their 30s…

It comes with some risk but the pay off is totally worth it.

The concept of a Mini Retirement is increasingly becoming popular…
 
Increasingly, a number of people in their 30s are frustrated that their jobs keep them so busy with such administrative and repetitive work that even if they want to learn new skills to stay relevant, there is absolutely no time with work meetings, travel to the office, family commitments and more…
 
And this is even more frustrating when people realize that their juniors are switching companies, taking bigger promotions, and their experience is rusting their ability to be hired elsewhere…
 
Which is why the concept of a mini retirement is picking up where people decide to take a break from work for around 12 months…
 
Which would mean building up a fund to last you a year of expenses, moving to a cheaper destination or a tier 2 city, and then spending the next six months on just learning new skills like AI, Blockchain, or in whatever domain you want to upskill in…

And then coming back to applying to newer roles in the latter half, giving yourself one year to upskill and restart your career…
 
Some people are also taking up part time freelancing gigs during this period which helps them stay in the zone of working about 10 hours a week, while keeping the remaining time free to learn.
 
Think it’s a low cost self taught MBA break because even MBA colleges are not being able to keep up with new skills in today’s time.
 
These breaks are also being called “Mini Retirements” on the resume instead of sabbaticals, which when asked about during an interview, gives you an opportunity to show how you are invested in learning even when your colleagues are just doing the old things.
 
Companies like Adobe, Linkedin and AirBnB also have extended leave programs that help retain talent and reduce burnout.
 
The stigma attached to it is definitely going away.
